Art appreciation is influenced by factors like weather, mood, and changes in the environment, and our projected emotions are reflected in the artwork. When looking at art, it accumulates layers of memories and personal growth, representing an active commitment to creating one's own history. The series of grape paintings by the artist Koh ryeo myung explores the relationship between reality and the underlying emptiness. The artist captures the essence of the subject by closely photographing grapes in an analog manner and then magnifying them to examine the materiality. He accentuates the tactile quality of grapes and highlights the most fundamental forms without providing any hints about the location of the grapes. This is an exploration of existentialism that looks at the meaning inherent in the subject itself. The pursuit of hyperrealism, in this case, doesn't aim for a precise reproduction of the subject but offers a new perspective by visualizing an exaggerated image. Grapes are often symbolic of life and abundance. Therefore, the artist's diverse grape series invites the viewer to confront a sense of overflowing richness. As the artist studies the colors inherent in the basic shape of grapes, he aims to express his aesthetic perspective. The colors produced by nature and the artistic vision perceived by the artist's touch guide the viewer to savor these grapes, which may seem familiar yet tantalizingly different
